content.p: a fire or combined installation on a premises;

intro.p: a general installation serving the following activities—

content.p: medical treatment of people or animals;
medical, pharmaceutical or chemical research and manufacturing;
agriculture, including dairies and nurseries;
photographic processing;
laundering and dry-cleaning;
metal plating; or
treatment of hides and skins;

intro.p: a general installation serving—

content.p: mortuaries;
abattoirs;
sewage purification works;
refuse pulverising works;
harbours;
oil processing and storage facilities;
wineries, distillers, breweries, yeast and cold drink factories;
sports fields; or

any other premises on which an activity is carried out which in the Municipality’s opinion is likely to cause a danger to health or affect the portability of water in the event of a substance resulting from such activity entering the water supply system; or
a general installation on any premises after issue of a written notice by the Municipality to do so.

intro.p: The measures required in terms of subsection (1) are—

content.p: the discharge of water from the service pipe into a storage tank through an air gap in accordance with the provisions of this By-law and any standards or conditions prescribed by the Municipality;

intro.p: the passing of such water through a—

content.p: reduced pressure backflow preventer; or
double check backflow preventer; or
any other measures accepted by the Municipality which achieve the same purpose as contemplated in paragraph (a) or (b).

intro.p: The owner must ensure that no connection is made to his or her service pipe between the—

content.p: point of discharge from the pipe into the storage tank contemplated in subsection (2)(a);
backflow preventer installed in accordance with subsection (2)(b); and
measure accepted in accordance with subsection 2(c) and the communication pipe concerned.

A customer may not connect anything to a water installation or use it in a manner which may affect the potability of the water in it without first ensuring that adequate measures or devices exist to prevent a deterioration in water quality in the water installation.

section.heading: Design and installation of backflow preventers

content.p: A backflow preventer must be so designed and installed that a condition of backflow in the pipe in which it is installed must be readily detected.

A backflow preventer must be installed in a readily accessible position where it can be inspected, and from which it can be removed for the purposes of servicing, repair and replacement without alteration to the water installation or the structure within which it is situated.
A backflow preventer which provides for the discharge of water to the atmosphere must be installed above ground in such a position that it cannot be submerged in water or other liquid.

section.heading: Inspection and servicing of backflow preventers

intro.p: The owner of premises on which a reduced pressure or double check backflow preventer is installed must, at his or her own expense, cause the backflow preventer to be—

content.p: inspected and serviced by a registered contractor at least once in every 12 months to ensure that it is in working order; and
replaced or completely overhauled once in every five years.
The owner must maintain a record of the inspections and services contemplated in subsection (1), in the manner determined by the Municipality.

intro.p: An owner must, by a measure described in subsection (2) which is agreed to by the authorised official, prevent the back syphonage into the water installation of a substance which is likely to cause a danger to health or affect the potability of water, in the case of—

content.p: a terminal water fitting which is so designed that a hose or other flexible pipe is, or can be, attached to it, which must include a hose bibcock, a laboratory tap, and a moveable shower unit;
a fire hose reel installed in a combined installation;
an underground irrigation system; or
any other fitting which may provide a contact between polluted water and the water installation.

intro.p: The measures required in terms of subsection (1) are a—

content.p: vacuum breaker situated on the highest point of an upstand which must be not less than 300 millimetres above the point of discharge of the highest terminal water fitting concerned;
terminal vacuum breaker situated not less than 300 millimetres above the highest point of connection of a pipe to a riser serving the fittings concerned; or
single check valve or vacuum breaker incorporated in, attached to or installed adjacent to, a terminal water fitting.
The lower point of discharge of the outlet of a terminal water fitting must be not less than 25 millimetres above a flood level of a fixed receptacle into which such fitting discharges.

intro.p: An owner must ensure that no inter-connection is made between a—

content.p: general installation and a fire installation if they are supplied through separate communication pipes; or

water installation carrying water supplied by the Municipality and an installation carrying water from another source of supply, unless backflow into such general installation or water installation cannot occur.
An owner must ensure that no inter-connection is made between a water installation, or other installation carrying potable water from any source, and a drain or sewer.

If the Municipality is of the opinion that an activity carried out or intended to be carried out on a premises could give rise to a substance which would have a toxic effect if it gained entry into a water installation, it may by written notice require the owner to install a storage tank from which the water required for such activity must be drawn.

The entry of water into the tank referred to in paragraph (6) must be solely from a pipe which discharges at a height of 75 millimetres or twice the diameter of the pipe, whichever is the greater, above the flood level rim of the tank.

section.heading: Unmetered supply of water for firefighting purposes

intro.p: If the Municipality supplies water for firefighting purposes to any premises through an unmetered connection, the Municipality may—

content.p: by written notice advise the owner of its intention to install a device at the cost of the owner and in a manner and position specified by it to indicate if water has been used in a fire installation; and
place a seal on the operating valve of every hydrant and hose reel in the fire installation served by such connection.
The provisions of section 19 of this By-law apply, with the necessary changes, to a device installed in accordance with subsection (1).

intro.p: If the Municipality inspects a fire installation and finds that a seal referred to in subsection (1)(b) is broken, or the device referred to in subsection (1)(a) indicates that water has been used from the fire installation, the Municipality may—

content.p: estimate the quantity of water which in its opinion has been drawn off from the installation since the previous inspection; and

intro.p: render an account to the customer for the—

content.p: quantity of water contemplated in paragraph (a); and
prescribed charge for the replacement of the seal.

intro.p: If the use of water for purposes other than firefighting has occurred on any premises, the Municipality may—

content.p: by written notice, require the customer on that premises within a specified period to cease using water from his or her fire installation for purposes other than firefighting; and

if a customer fails to comply with a notice served in accordance with paragraph (a), install a meter in the communication pipe serving the owner’s fire installation and charge the owner for the cost thereof.

If a customer uses water from his or her fire installation for purposes other than extinguishing or prevention of a fire or for maintenance purposes, he or she must notify the Municipality within three working days of such action.

intro.p: The nominal diameter of a communication pipe serving a fire installation may not be less than—

content.p: 25 millimetres, in the case of a fire or combined installation incorporating hose reels;
75 millimetres, in the case of an automatic sprinkler installation; or
100 millimetres, in the case of a fire or combined installation incorporating hydrants.

intro.p: The nominal diameter of a pipe in a fire installation supplying water to fire hydrants must not be less than—

content.p: 75 millimetres, if its length does not exceed 50 metres; and
100 millimetres, if its length exceeds 50 metres.

intro.p: The nominal diameter of a pipe serving hose reels on any one floor of a building may not be less than—

content.p: 25 millimetres, if it serves one or two hose reels;
32 millimetres, if it serves three hose reels;
40 millimetres, if it serves four or five hose reels; or
50 millimetres, if it serves more than five hose reels.
The pipe which serves a hydrant and hose reel installation must be provided with a twin pumping connection.
A pipe serving only hose reels which are situated in a building at a height of more than six metres above the ground level abutting on the building must be provided with a single pumping connection.

intro.p: A non-return valve must be installed in any fire installation between—

content.p: a pumping connection referred to in section 80(1) and (2); and
the communication pipe serving the installation.

A pipe which is connected to a storage tank and is provided with a pumping connection must be provided with a non-return valve installed in such a position and manner as to prevent the flow of water into the tank when the pumping connection is in operation.
A pressure gauge must be installed in a fire installation outside the building concerned, in a position where it can be observed without the necessity of entry into the building.
A test valve must be installed immediately upstream of the pressure gauge referred to in subsection (1).

intro.p: The pressure gauge referred to in subsection (1) must—

content.p: register a maximum pressure of not less than 2500 kilopascals;
be graduated at intervals of not less than 25 kilopascals; and
have an error of not more than 2% over its range of operation.
The Municipality may at any time operate the test valve and pressure gauge referred to in subsection (1).
Non-metallic pipes may not be installed above ground in either a fire installation or a combined installation.
No pipe in a fire installation may be enclosed in the same duct as a fuel or gas pipeline.

If a customer has reason to believe that a meter used for measuring water supplied to him or her by the Municipality is defective, he or she may, against payment of the prescribed charge, make application on the prescribed form for the meter to be tested.

intro.p: The prescribed charge contemplated in subsection (1) must be—

content.p: retained by the Municipality if the meter is found not to be defective; or
refunded to the applicant if the meter is found to be defective.

A meter to which the regulations relating to water meters published under the Trade Metrology Act, 1973 (Act No. 77 of 1973) are applicable, must be deemed to be defective if, when tested in accordance with such regulations, it is found to have a percentage error in over-registration or under-registration greater than that permitted for a meter in use in terms of those regulations.

intro.p: A meter to which the regulations contemplated in subsection (3) are not applicable, is deemed to be defective if, when tested at the following percentages of its designed maximum rate of flow—

content.p: not less than 75%;
between 50% and 55%; and
not more than 20%,

wrapUp.p: it is found to have a percentage error in over-registration or under-registration greater than 5% at any one of the said rates of flow.

section.heading: Adjustment of quantity of water supplied to customer through a defective meter

content.p: If a meter is found to be defective, the Municipality must estimate the quantity of water supplied to the customer during the period in which, in the opinion of the Municipality, the meter was defective.

intro.p: The estimate contemplated in paragraph (a) must be based on the basis of the average daily quantity of water supplied to the customer over a period—

content.p: between two successive meter readings subsequent to the replacement of the meter;
in the previous year corresponding to the period in which the meter was defective; or
of three months subsequent to the replacement of the meter, whichever the Municipality considers most appropriate.

If the quantity of water supplied to a customer during the period when his or her meter was defective cannot be estimated in terms of subsection (1), the Municipality may estimate such quantity on any basis that is available to it.

section.heading: Adjustment of account if meter is defective

content.p: The adjustment of the account of a customer who has been charged for water supplied through a defective meter, must be made over the period determined in accordance with section 95.

For the purpose of adjusting an account in terms of subsection (1) it must be deemed that the same quantity of water has been supplied in each interval of 24 hours during the period referred to in subsection (1).

intro.p: A person may not enter—
into an area used by the Municipality in connection with its water supply system—

content.p: which is enclosed by a fence; or
where entry is prohibited by notice boards; and
a structure used by the Municipality in connection with its water supply system, without prior written permission from the Municipality.
An unauthorised person may not interfere or tamper with the water supply system
A person may not make an illegal connection to the water supply system
A person may not damage or endanger the water supply system or cause or permit it to be damaged or endangered.

Any person who intends performing work which may cause damage to the water supply system on land, owned by or vested in the Municipality or over which it has a servitude or other right must, before beginning the work, obtain written confirmation from the Municipality as to whether any part of the water supply system is situated on that land and, if so, the location of that water supply system.

If an authorised official believes that any work which is being performed or is to be performed on land contemplated in subsection (2), or on land adjacent thereto, could damage or endanger the water supply system, he or she may by notice in writing require the person concerned not to commence, or to cease performing, the work until such time as that person has complied with the conditions specified in the notice.

section.heading: Obstruction of access to water supply system

content.p: A person may not prevent or restrict access to the water supply system.

intro.p: If any person contravenes the provisions of subsection (1), the Municipality may—

content.p: by written notice require the person to restore access at his or her own cost within a period specified in the notice; and
if it believes that access must be restored as a matter of urgency, without prior notice, restore access and recover the cost from the person who contravened the provisions of subsection (1).

intro.p: A person may not do anything which causes, or might cause, the pollution of water in—

content.p: a reservoir; or

any other place owned, controlled by or vested in the Municipality either in whole or in part, and used by it in connection with the supply of water, unless that act is specifically authorised in writing by the Municipality.

A person may not, deposit or discharge any waste as defined in the Municipality's Waste Removal By-law, on any portion of a catchment area relating to the Municipality’s water supply which has been designated by notice boards as being an area where such acts are prohibited, except at places that are designated by notice boards or in receptacles that have been provided by the Municipality.,

intro.p: In the event that a person contravenes the provisions of subsection (1) or (2), the Municipality may—

content.p: give notice in writing, requiring the person to immediately stop the contravention and take specified action within a specified period; or
if it believes that action is urgently required, without prior notice, take such steps as it deems necessary to remedy the situation and recover the costs from the person in contravention.

A person may not lay or construct a pipe or an associated component on, in or under a street, public place or other land owned by, vested in, or under the control of the Municipality, without the prior written permission of the Municipality and subject to such conditions as it may impose.
All water supplied by the Municipality must be paid for by the customer at the prescribed charge for that particular category of use for which the supply was granted.
A customer must pay for all water supplied to him or her from the date of the agreement to supply water until the date of termination of that agreement.

The Municipality may estimate a quantity of water supplied in respect of a period or periods within the interval between actual successive readings of the meter and may render an account to a customer for the quantity of water so estimated to have been supplied to him or her during each such period.
The amount of an account rendered for water supplied to a customer becomes due and payable on the due date stipulated in the account.

If a customer is dissatisfied with an account rendered for water supplied to him or her by the Municipality, he or she may, prior to the date stipulated in the account, object in writing to the account and setting out his or her reasons for the objection: Provided that the lodging of an objection does not entitle a customer to defer payment, except with the written consent of the Municipality.

intro.p: If a customer uses water for a category of use other than that for which it is supplied by the Municipality, and as a result is—

content.p: not charged for water so used; or
charged for the water at a rate lower than that at which he or she should be charged,
such customer is liable for the amount due to the Municipality in accordance with the prescribed charges in respect of the—
quantity of water which, in the Municipality’s opinion, the customer has used and for which he or she has not been charged; or
difference between the cost of the water used by the customer at the rate at which he or she has been charged and the cost of the water at the rate at which he or she should have been charged.

section.heading: Amendments to prescribed charges for water supplied

content.p: If amendments to the prescribed charges for water supplied become operative on a date between meter readings, it must be deemed, for the purpose of rendering an account in respect of the charges, that the same quantity of water was supplied in each period of 24 hours during the interval between the meter readings.

section.heading: No reduction of amount payable for water wasted or leakage undetected

intro.p: A customer is not entitled to a reduction of the amount payable for water supplied to him or her if—

content.p: water is wasted; or
a leak in his or her water installation is undetected.

intro.p: The Municipality may, in addition to the prescribed charges for water consumed, prescribe and levy any of the following charges:

content.p: a monthly charge payable by the owner in respect of premises which in the opinion of the Municipality can reasonably be connected to the water supply system but is not so connected, the charge being due from a date determined by the Municipality, until the date of the agreement to supply water;

a charge payable by the customer in respect of each communication pipe or meter provided by the Municipality to serve the premises occupied by him or her, whether or not water has been supplied to him or her, the charge being due from the date of the agreement to supply water; and
a monthly charge payable by a customer in respect of a minimum quantity of water, whether or not water has actually been supplied to him or her.
The Municipality may grant a temporary supply of water from one or more fire hydrants specified by it.
A person who desires a temporary supply of water referred to in subsection (1) must make an application to the Municipality on the prescribed form in accordance with section 7.

Water supplied in accordance with subsection (1) must pass through a meter and The meter together with the appurtenant apparatus required to enable it to be connected to a hydrant must be provided by the Municipality and remains the Municipality’s property.

intro.p: Before an applicant is provided with a meter in accordance with subsection (3), he or she must pay a—

content.p: deposit contemplated in section 11; and
prescribed deposit in respect of each meter and appurtenant apparatus supplied by the Municipality, as security for their return in proper working order.

If the Municipality requires that an authorised official be in control of the installation of the meter provided in accordance with subsection (3), the customer must pay the prescribed charge for the attendance of the authorised official.

intro.p: If the Municipality does not require an authorised official to be in control in accordance with subsection (5), a customer to whom a meter and appurtenant apparatus are supplied in accordance with subsection (3) is responsible for the safekeeping and the proper use thereof and must—

content.p: return the meter forthwith if it is damaged or becomes defective;
make the meter available for reading purposes before the seventh (7th) day of each month, or at such other intervals as the Municipality may prescribe, at a place designated by it; and
return the meter and apparatus to the Municipality on the termination of the agreement for supply.
The customer must, in addition to paying for the water supplied to him or her by the Municipality, pay the prescribed charge for the use of a meter which is supplied to him or her.

If a customer fails to comply with subsection 6(a), (b) or (c), the Municipality may render an account to him or her for a quantity of water which it deems to have been supplied to him or her since the last reading of the meter concerned, basing such quantity on the maximum specified rate of flow of the meter in continuous use over a period of eight hours per day for five days per week or on such lesser rate or period as the Municipality deems appropriate.

The charge contemplated in paragraph (a) must continue to be levied until the customer returns the meter and appurtenant apparatus or notifies the Municipality in writing that he or she is unable to do so.

Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph (a) and (b), if a customer returns the meter in working order and with its seal intact after being charged for water in accordance with paragraph (a), the Municipality must adjust the amount charged to the cost of the water actually supplied to him or her.

intro.p: If a customer to whom water is supplied in accordance with subsection (1)—

content.p: takes water from a hydrant which is not specified by the Municipality;
is found to be taking, or to have taken, water from a hydrant without its passing through a meter; or
fails to comply with any provision of subsection (6),

wrapUp.p: the Municipality may terminate his or her agreement for the supply.

section.heading: Resale of water supplied by Municipality

intro.p: A customer who is supplied with water in terms of this By-law may not sell such water unless—

content.p: provision has been made for such sale in a special agreement as contemplated in section 8; or
he or she has obtained the prior written permission of the Municipality to do so.
If the Municipality grants the permission contemplated in subsection (1), it may stipulate the maximum price at which the water may be sold and impose such other conditions as it deems fit.
The Municipality may at any time withdraw the permission contemplated in subsection (1).
The owner of a premises, and not the tenant, is liable in respect of the charges for water supplied to that premises.

The Municipality may prescribe conditions and requirements relating to the metering of water supplied to different categories of customers, and the liability of those customers to pay the prescribed charges for water supplied.

intro.p: The Municipality may prescribe the following after following the public participation process contemplated in section 23:

content.p: a leak repair policy;
a credit control and debt collection policy relating to water supplied to domestic customers;
a debt relief policy; or
a policy dealing with free basic water services for indigent people.

Domestic customers are entitled to insure themselves against undetected underground leaks by payment of a monthly premium to the Municipality, which is raised on the consolidated bill and forwarded to a private insurance company.
The relationship is between the customer and the private insurance company and the Municipality acquires no obligations in respect of any insurance which a customer may choose to acquire.
The customer’s account may be suspended for disconnections to water for a period of 60 days to facilitate the insurance process contemplated in subsection (1).
Accounts may not be suspended where there are disputes with respect to the amount paid by the insurance company.

An adjustment determined in accordance with the terms and conditions of the water loss insurance policy for individually metered dwelling units, will be made in respect of sewage disposal charges raised against any domestic or non-domestic customer where the sewage disposal charges arise from any underground water leaks which were repaired correctly and timeously.
Domestic residential customers supplied via a semi-pressure supply are entitled to a reduction on the standard tariff for consumption of up to 30 kilolitres per month.

When water consumption is recorded on a property during a period for which there is no registered customer against whom a bill can be raised, the relevant charges for water services must be raised against the registered owner on his or her consolidated bill.
The executor of a deceased estate is liable, in his or her official capacity as such, for the payment of all debts on the property.

intro.p: Where the estate has not been finalised, the occupants of the property are deemed to be the owners for the purposes of any amounts due relating to water services provided that the deemed owner may, subject to the terms and conditions of the Municipality's water policy, apply for—

content.p: a flow limiter; and
the debt relief programme.
A notice or document issued by the Municipality in terms of this By-law must be deemed to be duly issued if it is signed by an authorised official.

intro.p: If a notice or document is to be served on a person in terms of this By-law, such service must be effected—

content.p: by delivering it to him or her personally or to his or her duly authorised agent;

intro.p: by delivering it at his or her residence or place of business or employment to a person apparently—

content.p: not less than 16 years of age; and
residing or employed there;
if he or she has nominated an address for the receipt of notices and other legal documents, by delivering it to that address;

if he or she has not nominated an address for the receipt of notices and other legal documents, by delivering it to the address given by him or her in his or her application for a supply of water, for the reception of an account for water supplied;
in the case of a body corporate, by delivering it at the registered office or business premises of such body corporate;

by registered or certified post addressed to his or her last known address; or (g) if service cannot be effected in accordance with paragraphs (a) to (f), by affixing it to a principal door of entry to the premises concerned.

The Municipality may by written notice order a person who is in contravention of this By-law or any condition or requirement prescribed in terms of this By-law to stop that contravention within a period specified in the notice.

If a person fails to comply with a written notice served on him or her in terms of this By-law within the specified period, the Municipality may take such action or do such work as it deems necessary to ensure compliance, and recover the costs of such action or work from such person.
A person may not make a false statement or furnish false information to the Municipality, nor falsify a document issued in terms of this By-law.

The Municipality may, by following the public participation procedure referred to in section 23, prescribe any standard, condition, requirement, policy or any other matter required for the implementation of this By-law.

If authority was given before the date of commencement of this By-law for installation work to be done, or if authorised work is in progress on such date, such work must comply with any laws governing such work which were in force in the area of jurisdiction of the Municipality prior to the date of commencement of this By-law.

The Municipality may, for a period of 90 days after the date of commencement of this By-law, give authority for installation work to be done in accordance with any laws governing such work which were in force in the area of jurisdiction of the Municipality prior to the date of commencement of this By-law.

intro.p: It is the responsibility of the—

content.p: owner of the premises to comply with the provisions of this By-law in respect of the water installation; and
customer to comply with the provisions of this By-law in respect of the use of the water on the premises.

An owner may not be required to comply with this By-law by altering a water installation or a part thereof which was installed in conformity with any law applicable immediately before the date of commencement of this By-law.

Notwithstanding subsection (1), the Municipality may by notice in writing require the owner to comply with the provisions of this By-law within a specified period, if it is of the opinion that the installation or a part thereof is so defective or in such a condition or position as to cause, or be likely to cause, waste or undue consumption of water, pollution, pollution of the water supply, or a health or safety hazard.

section.heading: Use of water from sources other than the water supply system

intro.p: A person may not use or permit the use of water obtained from a source other than the water supply system, except with the prior consent of the Municipality and in accordance with such conditions as it may impose, for—

content.p: domestic, commercial or industrial purposes; or
the purpose of filling a swimming pool.

intro.p: Any person desiring the consent contemplated in subsection (1) must provide evidence to the satisfaction of the Municipality that the—

content.p: water referred to in subsection (1) complies, whether as a result of treatment or otherwise, with the requirements of SANS 241-1 relating to drinking water contained in Part 1: Microbiological, physical, aesthetic and chemical determinants; and
use of such water does not or will not constitute a danger to health.

intro.p: Any consent given in accordance with subsection (1) may be withdrawn if in the opinion of the Municipality—

content.p: a condition imposed in accordance with subsection (1) is breached; or
the water no longer conforms to the requirements contemplated in subsection (2).

If water obtained from a borehole or other source of supply on a premises is used for a purpose which gives rise to the discharge of such water or a portion thereof into the Municipality’s sewerage system, the Municipality may install a meter in the pipe leading from such borehole or other source of supply to the point or points where it is so used.
The provisions of section 20 apply, with the necessary changes, in respect of the meter contemplated in subsection (4).

intro.p: The Municipality may by public notice require the—

content.p: owner of any premises upon which a borehole exists or, if the owner is not in occupation of such premises, the occupier thereof, to notify the Municipality on the prescribed form of the existence of a borehole on the premises, and provide it with such information as the Municipality may require; and
owner or occupier of a premises who intends to sink a borehole on the premises to notify it on the prescribed form of such intention before work in connection therewith is commenced.

The Municipality may take samples of water obtained from a source other than the water supply system and cause the samples to be tested for compliance with the requirements contemplated in section 114.
The prescribed charge for the taking and testing of the samples contemplated in subsection (1) must be paid by the person to whom consent to use the water was granted.
The Municipality may on application in terms of section 7, grant a supply of non-potable water to a customer.
Any supply of water granted in accordance with subsection (1) may not be used for domestic or any other purpose which, in the opinion of the Municipality, may give rise to a health hazard.

section.heading: Conditions of supply of non-potable water

content.p: No warranty, expressed or implied, applies to the purity of any non-potable water supplied by the Municipality or its suitability for the purpose for which the supply was granted.
The supply of non-potable water is entirely at the risk of the customer, both as to condition and use.

The customer is liable for any consequential damage or loss arising to him or herself or others caused directly or indirectly from the supply of non-potable water, including the consequences of any bona fide fault of the Municipality or malfunction of a treatment plant.

section.heading: Use of non-potable water for irrigation purposes

content.p: If non-potable water supplied by the Municipality is used for irrigation purposes, the customer must ensure that it is applied uniformly over the irrigated areas and in such a way as to prevent ponding.
The customer must, at his or her own expense, take such steps as may be necessary to prevent any run-off of surplus non-potable water from irrigated areas.
If the customer fails to take the steps contemplated in subsection (2), the Municipality may by written notice require him or her to take steps within a specified period.
If the customer fails to comply with the written notice as contemplated in subsection (3), the Municipality may take such steps at the expense of the customer.

On premises on which non-potable water is used, the customer must ensure that every terminal water fitting and every appliance which supplies or uses such water is clearly marked with a weather-proof notice indicating that the water is unsuitable for domestic purposes.
In an area where treated sewage effluent is used, the customer must erect weather-­proof notices in prominent positions warning that such effluent is not suitable for domestic purposes.
Every warning notice contemplated in subsections (1) and (2) must be in English, isiZulu and Afrikaans, and any such other language as the Municipality may deem necessary.

An authorised official may for any purpose connected with the implementation or enforcement of this By-law, at all reasonable times or in an emergency at any time, enter the premises, request information and make such inspection, examination and enquiry as he or she may deem necessary, and for those purposes operate any component of the water installation.

intro.p: If the authorised official considers it necessary that work be performed to enable him or her to properly and effectively implement a function contemplated in subsection (1), the authorised official may—

content.p: by written notice, require the owner or occupier of the premises at his or her own cost, to do specified work within a specified period; and
if in his or her opinion the situation is a matter of urgency, without prior notice do such work or cause it to be done, at the cost of the owner.

Only in the event that the work contemplated in subsection (2) is carried out for the sole purpose of establishing whether a contravention of this By-law has been committed and no such contravention is established, the Municipality must bear the expenses connected therewith together with that of restoring the premises to its former condition.

intro.p: If an authorised official requires the presence of—

content.p: an owner at an inspection of his or her water installation;
a registered contractor doing installation work at an inspection of such work; or
a registered contractor’s responsible plumber at an inspection of work being done under his or her control,

wrapUp.p: he or she may give such person written notice of not less than two working days to that effect, indicating the date and time when, and the place where, he or she proposes to carry out the inspection.

content.p: The Municipality and any authorised official are not liable to any third party for any damage caused by anything lawfully done or omitted by the Municipality or the authorised official in carrying out any function or duty in terms of this By-law.
Failure to comply with a lawful request of the authorised official constitutes a contravention of this By-law.

intro.p: If a person—

content.p: contravenes the provisions of this By-law; or
fails or refuses to comply with a compliance notice issued in terms of this By­-law,

wrapUp.p: the Municipality may take any steps required in order to address or rectify such non-compliance, and recover the costs from such person responsible.

content.p: Any liability contemplated in paragraph (a) is in addition to any fine which may be imposed on such person.

intro.p: The Municipality may, on a case by case basis, relax or waive the requirements of a provision of this By-law upon such conditions as it deems fit to impose and if it is of the opinion—

content.p: that the application or operation of that provision in that particular case would be so unreasonable as to cause substantial prejudice of a nature or degree which was not intended to flow from the enactment of the provision; and

intro.p: that the—

content.p: purpose for which the provision has been enacted has substantially been attained in that case or will be so attained upon compliance with the conditions imposed; or
need to attain that purpose is for any reason absent in the particular case.

intro.p: A person is guilty of an offence under this By-law if he or she—

content.p: unlawfully prevents the authorised official entry to his or her premises or causes or permits any other person to prevent entry;
obstructs or hinders the authorised official in the performance of his or her duties or causes or permits any other person to so obstruct or hinder the authorised official;
refuses or fails to provide to the authorised official such information as is required to allow the authorised official to perform a function in terms of this By­-law;
knowingly gives false or misleading information to an authorised official;
impersonates an authorised official;
contravenes or fails to comply with any provision of this By-law; or
contravenes or fails to comply with any order or notice lawfully issued under this By-law.

Any person who is convicted of an offence under this By-law shall be liable to a fine of an amount not exceeding R300 000 or to imprisonment for a period not exceeding three years, or to both such fine and imprisonment.

Failure to comply with the terms of this By-law or any terms of any condition or notice shall constitute a continuing offence and a person failing to comply with the terms of such condition or notice shall be guilty of a separate offence for each day during which he or she fails to comply with such terms.

In addition to the penalties prescribed in this By-law and any other law, a person liable in terms of subsection (1) and (2) shall also be held liable to such charges as an authorised officer may assess as the full cost including the environmental cost incurred by the Municipality as a result of that offence.

intro.p: Subject to the Constitution and applicable national and provincial laws, any—

content.p: power, excluding a power referred to in section 160(2) of the Constitution;
function; or
duty,

wrapUp.p: conferred, in terms of this By-law, upon the Municipality, or on any of the other political structures, political office bearers, councillors or staff members of the Municipality, may be delegated or sub-delegated by such political structure, political office bearer, councillor, or staff member, to an entity within, or a staff member employed by, the Municipality.

content.p: The delegation contemplated in subsection (1) must be effected in line with the system of delegations adopted by the Municipality in accordance with section 59(1) of the Local Government: Municipal Systems Act, 2000 (Act No.32 of 2000), subject to the criteria set out in section 59(2) of the said Act.

intro.p: Any delegation contemplated in this section must be recorded in the Register of Delegations, which must contain information on the—

content.p: entity or person issuing the delegation or sub-delegation;
recipient of the delegation or sub-delegation; and
conditions attached to the delegation or sub-delegation.

A person whose rights are affected by a decision taken by the Municipality in terms of this By-law may appeal against that decision in terms of section 62 of the Local Government: Municipal Systems Act, 2000 (Act No. 32 of 2000) by giving written notice of the appeal and reasons thereof to the municipal manager within 21 days of the date of the notification of the decision.
The Municipal Manager must act in accordance with the provisions outlined in section 62 of the Municipal Systems Act, 2000 in response to the appeal.
The laws mentioned in the first and second columns of the Schedule to this By­-law are hereby repealed to the extent set out in the third column of the said Schedule.
All notices published under the Water Supply By-law of 1996 remain in full force and effect as if the said By-law has not been repealed as contemplated in subsection (1)
Any rights accrued or obligations incurred as contemplated in the laws referred to in subsection (2) remain in force, as if those laws have not been repealed.

This By-law is called the eThekwini Municipality: Water By-law, 2022 and takes effect six months from the date of publication thereof in the Provincial Gazette or on such earlier date as may be determined by the publication of a commencement notice in the Provincial Gazette.
